title: When will the Public Health Agency of Canada (PHAC) report 1.1 million or more total cases of COVID-19 in Canada?
preds: Didn's expect this wave in my previous forecast. Big change 1,1 million will be reached this month

No sign of slowing.
A daily increase of >6k cases over the past seven days on average indicates the threshold will be met within two weeks c.p.

today:1,000,545
Since my last forecast 15 days ago, +72,976=>4,865/day 
If 4,865/day=>21 days=>Between 1 April 2021 and 30 April 2021
At the current pace, on track for 1.1m on about April 22.

A new wave looks to be underway in numerous provinces, driven by variants. Vaccination rates are simply too low/slow right now to combat this, and may not be fully effective against the variants anyway. Lockdown measures are increasing, but will have a lagging effect on new cases.

New reactive restrictions being imposed across Ontario [1] signal the delayed realisation of the third wave that was arguably inevitable with the relaxation of measures and the slow pace of the vaccination programme.  That said the last 48 hours on here are testament to how so many were caught out with the exponential rise in cases in the relatively short period (including me!) and how impactful the UK COVID variant (B.1.1.7) [2] can be on case rates in more relaxed transmission environments. Note a similar rise in cases across the border in Michigan [3] which may play into anyone's forecast on this question's cousin regarding relaxation of US / Canadian travel restrictions [4]. Newly imposed restrictions carry with them the inevitable 2 week lag time for measurable impact on case rate and transmission, meaning the 1.1 million mark in late April 2021 (estimating 24th - 27th April 21 window at this moment with an average of roughly 4750 -5000 over the remaining period) seems to be as certain as anything legitimately can be called at this moment. Experienced an interesting resistance to making the flip from May to April 21 on this one given family links and natural affinity for Canada (as a UK resident).  Without that "wish" for it not to be so I might have made the switch a couple of days earlier... [1] https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/covid-19-ontario-shutdown-hospital-intensive-care-icu-patients-1.5969831
[2] https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/transmission/variant.html
[3] https://eu.detroitnews.com/story/news/local/michigan/2021/03/30/cdc-michigan-covid-19-new-cases-most-in-united-states/7059595002/
[4] https://www.gjopen.com/questions/1817-when-will-canada-next-permit-discretionary-travel-for-foreign-nationals-arriving-from-the-united-states
Third wave. Renewed restrictions and vaccines will help but both are too little too late. Late April/early May border if people follow the new rules. April if they don’t.

Current cases = 976,598
Cases remaining = 123,402
Current 7 day rolling average = 4,656 Days until April 30 = 30
Cases per day to hit 1.1 million by April 30 = 4,113 Days until May 31 = 61
Cases per day to hit 1.1 million by May 31 = 2,022 Currently on track to hit 1.1 million cases in April. Increasing likelihood of April and May. https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2020-03-01..latest&country=~CAN&region=World&casesMetric=true&interval=smoothed&smoothing=7&pickerMetric=total_cases&pickerSort=desc
Average needed to get to 1.1m by end April is now 4K per day.  Current rates are at this level and creeping up, so predicting April.

With these margin call predictions it may be worth mentioning, for anyone using the more accessible and visually pleasant “our world indata” website [1] that the PHAC website against which this question will be decided [2] consistently lags about 5000 to 6000 cases per day behind it in total figures.  This means that the Question will probably resolve a day or so after the world in data site  records crossing the 1.1 mil threshold (for anyone tracking a prediction that falls on the 29th or 30th April 21 boundary!). [1] https://ourworldindata.org/explorers/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=286..432&pickerSort=desc&pickerMetric=total_cases&Metric=Confirmed+cases&Interval=7-day+rolling+average&Relative+to+Population=false&Align+outbreaks=false&country=~CAN
[2] https://health-infobase.canada.ca/covid-19/epidemiological-summary-covid-19-cases.html?stat=num&measure=total&map=pt#a2

Currently at 965k. Currently, exponential growth, with doubling time for #cases/day a bit over a month. B.1.1.7 and other more transmissible variants. Immune escape variants. Only 9% have received at least one dose of vaccine as of March 20. Bad situation. But, heading into spring, which will help a bit.
Canada won't see 1.1M cases by April 1.
Currently, about 4.3k cases/day. If cases stayed absolutely flat at this level, there would be 146.2k more cases by April 30. 965k + 146.2k = 1.11M.
I don't see any way that cases will maintain an average as low as 4.3k through April, as B.1.1.7 becomes dominant and control policies are not implemented. I expect the number of cases/day to continue to grow through April, with at most some slowing in the rate of growth due to weather or changes in individual behavior. Update 4/1: Total at 988k cases, with 5.5k cases/day and climbing exponentially. Canada should arrive at 1.1M cases by around April 17.
Chance that lockdowns slow the rise in the remaining time. Otherwise, no change in rationale.

Major adjustment given case rate continued rise, historical trend in previous waves and lack of any obvious corrective action being taken to curb it.  Combined with the slow pace of vaccinations, the advantage seems to be to the virus at this stage. It looks like a margin call between buckets 3 and 4 but is seems the greater likelihood at this moment falls an earlier rather than later crossing of the 1.1mil threshold. https://ourworldindata.org/explorers/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=271..430&pickerSort=desc&pickerMetric=total_cases&Metric=Confirmed+cases&Interval=7-day+rolling+average&Relative+to+Population=false&Align+outbreaks=false&country=~CAN
Set to hit 1 million next week.
What's stopping it? Everything is rising, everything is opening. The numbers are crunching April.

942,320 so 158k to go
Current rolling daily average is now 3.7k.
At 3k per day it’s 57 days eta May 27
At 3.7k per day it’s 43 days eta May 13
At 4K per day it’s 40 days eta May 10 Previous eta forecast of may 19 is possible, but likely to come forward, but in order to get into April will need to go up over 4.4K average.  This could happen too.

Moving bucket spread a little as cases continue to rise. https://ourworldindata.org/explorers/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=310..latest&pickerSort=desc&pickerMetric=total_cases&Metric=Confirmed+cases&Interval=7-day+rolling+average&Relative+to+Population=false&Align+outbreaks=false&country=~CAN

SPIKE upward in cases. I now forecast it to reach 1.1M around May 2, 2021—if not sooner.

But it could be very close... https://ourworldindata.org/explorers/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=321..422&pickerSort=desc&pickerMetric=total_cases&Metric=Confirmed+cases&Interval=7-day+rolling+average&Relative+to+Population=false&Align+outbreaks=false&country=~CAN
A little too confident in my last thinking.

The daily new cases have been climbing away from baseline for almost 2 weeks now, even with vaccines, more knowledge of the vaccines, proper hygiene, and lockdown needs, etc. It's not a crazy growth so this may not trigger a lockdown fast enough to curb the growth. If growth stopped right now at 3.3k, mid May is where we will see 1.1M.

Canada
/finally increased test intensity (100k tests per day v <80k tests)
/now has three provinces (BC, Alberta, Ontario) with more than 1,000 proven cases of variant B.1.1.7
/a second province where all three variants under scrutiny are spreading: BC, which has probably introduced a thorough surveillance
/has only one major populous province, Quebec, with stable day counts of cases; however, Quebec is vulnerable due to geographical proximity to Ontario, and it seems to develop a serious issue with the variant first observed in South Africa (B.1.351)
/the only good news I currently see is that active cases dropped below 30k, but this may be a side effect of passage of time only  While testing is a good sign of getting outbreaks under control again, it comes "too little, too late".Before 31 March 2021, Canada will be in a situation where daily new confirmed cases will have risen beyond 4.5k and rising, and 1.1m before 30 April will appear inevitable.
Canada's R-naught value is back over 1.0 and cases have been sloooooowly rising. This could push it over the edge toward end of April. I did the math (and no, not linearly).

921k on March 16, 7 day rolling average of 3155 and holding reasonably flat for about a month (source: https://ourworldindata.org/explorers/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=40..420&pickerSort=asc&pickerMetric=location&Metric=Confirmed+cases&Interval=7-day+rolling+average&Relative+to+Population=false&Align+outbreaks=false&country=~CAN) At the current rate, it would be 57 days from March 16, or May 13. To be before May 1 (45 days from now) would require an average of 3972 cases/day. Canada's vaccination rate is accelerating but they've only administered 8.67 doses per 100 people, a middling result. With more contagious variants spreading, I expect the average number of cases to increase in Canada, rather than decrease, though I would need to see an acceleration before favoring April to May.

Decrease is cases is slower than expected in Januari. Still even keeping the current growth rate (+-3.000 confimed cases per day) 1.1 million total cases will not be reached until halfway through May. With the weather improving and vaccination slowly getting underway I increase the change of not reaching 1.1 million before 1st of June.

I am shifting my confidence it may reach 1.1M by late April. I have been calculating the growth rate for weeks now and each time it shifts closer to the first of May. It *may* crossover to April, which is not entirely impossible. Many COVID models tend to have a higher uncertainty spread for jumps in cases than drops in cases, anyway. The next forecast update I will make, I will include more factors into my thinking and it may significantly switch more percentage points to April away from May and Not before 1 June. For instance, there is a climb in cases in Canada, further making April more likely.

Adjusting confidence based on latest trend projections seeming determined to hover between 3000 & 3500 cases per day (7 day average). https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2021-01-15..latest&country=~CAN&region=World&casesMetric=true&interval=smoothed&smoothing=7&pickerMetric=total_cases&pickerSort=desc

Rate now running at 3k per week. This makes an earlier date in May more likely based on my previous forecast rational.
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1243295 200k to go at 3k per day is 67 days = eta is still 19 May A slight uptick also means rates are unlikely to drop much to go into June.  Upping prob for May.

And the Crowd forecast more and more this since a few weeks Vaccines and the season may slow down the number of cases in the coming weeks.
Vaccines and the season may cause the number of cases to slow down in the coming weeks, so I will re-evaluate my prediction once a week with the new numbers from the past week

Active cases (30.6k) and the spread of variants of concern (2,728 B.1.1.7 in total) are on the rise, and Ontario seems to become the epicenter of all trouble: All three VoC currently under scrutiny are now domiciled in Ontario in significant numbers.
956 B.1.1.7; 41 B.1.351; 28 P.1
Reports from Germany are worrying that there are cases with a variant on record that are by and large cross-variants of B.1.1.7&B.1.351. If those combinations occur in CA, too, the real trouble likely begins.
Canada is 200k cases and 50 days from the most interesting bin threshold away, so 4k new cases a day for the next seven weeks on average is the standard to watch.

New cases have started to stabilize after declining from peak of second wave.  Unfortunately they are stabilizing above 2500 cases per day.  If that holds it is still possible to have more than 1.1 M cases by 30 April with a small uptick in daily new cases. Also - currently only 5% of population has been vaccinated.  Vaccination rate is starting to accelerate but has not yet made a significant impact.

The good news is: the virus seems to be under control in Alberta, British Columbia, which means suppression of the B.1.1.7 variant there at the same time.
The bad news: Ontario's numbers tend to surge, 1,185 as of 09 March 2021 (which is ~40% of Canada's daily total), active cases are still higher than 30k, B.1.1.7 is still gaining (2,480 cases know from Dec 2020) in incidence, and Ontario is host to that variant predominantly (908 known cases, 37% of the total)

Updating confidence based on trend and reporting on new variants.

All rolling averages trending downwards.  From last update, the Canadians need to hit an average of ~3800/day to hit bucket 3. A number they passed once in the last 3 weeks.  If they can reduce the number below ~1900/day we can hit bucket 5, while the number is trending downwards, I think it's possible, but unlikely given the rate the numbers are reducing. A significant unknow is the impact of warmer weather on these numbers and if the simple shift to summer will drop the transmissions through the floor.

Experts warning of potential third wave in population hubs with variants and increasing relaxation of lockdowns being described as a potential “forest fire”. https://toronto.ctvnews.ca/ugly-third-wave-of-covid-19-around-april-inevitable-for-ontario-expert-says-1.5303510
https://globalnews.ca/news/7639265/coronavirus-canada-third-wave/

Current levelling out of case rates (determinedly hanging around the 3000 a day average) seems set to continue for the next 2 weeks at least, and with little public commentary on cause and no published change to Government containment policy thus far has the potential to last for longer than that. Historical trend line over warmer weather seems likely to still see a gradual decline in case numbers over the question period, but there is also the increasing potential of lockdown fatigue, complacency and warmer weather socialisation that may see localised spikes in population centres. The more industrialised Alberta also seems to be having a hard time getting their arms around case numbers (although the nation as a whole is seeing a steady drop in deaths to the credit of their health system) which may be due to a number of local nuances and the greater presence of close in working environments e.g meat packing plants (previously identified hot spots [1]). In short, confidence in the previously projected 2500~3500 a day average over the question period has gone up. [1] https://globalnews.ca/video/6896174/alberta-meat-packing-plant-to-close-for-one-week-for-deep-clean-after-employee-tests-positive-for-covid-19

Tracking adjustment as the case average takes a steady turn upwards (and looks likely to continue to do so for at least the next two weeks as detection catches up with infection). https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/this-isn-t-a-wave-it-s-a-forest-fire-experts-predict-rise-of-covid-19-variant-cases-in-canada-1.5307870

The B 1.1.7 variant seems to have the capacity to change the game in Canada by April already, with a focus on British Columbia, as the latest "Update on COVID-19 in Canada: Epidemiology and Modelling" (as of 19 Feb 2021, sheets 10, 12, 16) suggests. The next two weeks could be crucial to contain the variant, and prevent an exponential resurgence from happening.
https://www.canada.ca/content/dam/phac-aspc/documents/services/diseases-maladies/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/epidemiological-economic-research-data/update-covid-19-canada-epidemiology-modelling-20210219-en.pdf @Mark_T

National turning of the downwards trend line [1] and news from BC [2] is concerning, in part due to the uptick in case numbers at a local level but potentially more so as an indicator of complacency and COVID fatigue setting in. Bearing in mind the 2 week lag in case detection and data tracing, these numbers may get worse before they get better, so the government response to this news will define if and how this may turn into a wider outbreak (see Australia’s response as a comparison of approach).  If, as reporting suggests, this uptick in cases is largely amongst the younger parts of the population then earlier assumptions on a case reduction in the summer time (as per 2020) may be more fragile / less impactful on case numbers. That said, death rates are still reducing so every cloud... Until more data comes in on this potential change in infection rates comes in I'm returning to my earlier premise that 3000 cases per day may be the rough average over the question period, landing the 1.1 million case point around late May 21. [1] https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2020-08-28..latest&country=~CAN&region=World&casesMetric=true&interval=smoothed&smoothing=7&pickerMetric=total_cases&pickerSort=desc
[2] https://bc.ctvnews.ca/video?clipId=1993890

+5 in June bucket to stay ahead of he crowd.
Minor adjustment based on increased confidence with previous forecast.
3667 / day as of Feb 6. Dropping {comma} but not as fast as I thought two weeks ago.

Data trends, case rates (7 day rolling averages seem to be the most useful) and balances of vaccines, new variants, warmer weather over coming months, the Canadian Governments "risk sensible" approach to applying / lifting restrictions and the generally high level of compliance and cooperation across the Canadian public have moved my projected "over the period" average to between 2000 & 2500 cases per day (down from 3500 per day for my previous forecasts). This has moved the 1.1 million marker to between late (26th) May 21 and early June 21, with mid - late June 21 / early July 21 being at the (still credible but more wild card fragile) end of the bell curve. Big things to watch and adjust on will be new variants taking hold in the Canadian population, any lifting of restrictions without a high degree of vaccinated "herd immunity" and a loss of confidence, cooperation and compliance in high density population areas. All these factors could cause "off trend line" escalations in case numbers.  Also need to factor in the 2 - 3 week delay between something changing and the data reflecting the impact. https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2020-02-28..latest&country=~CAN&region=World&casesMetric=true&interval=smoothed&smoothing=7&pickerMetric=total_cases&pickerSort=desc
https://health-infobase.canada.ca/covid-19/?stat=rate&measure=total#a2
Currently weekly reduction in new cases is ~ 15%. Even if this weekly reduction in new cases changes to only ~4.5%, Canada will not reach 1.1 million cases before 1 June

With historical impact of slowly warming weather on case rates and new variant ‘wild cards’ accounted for the trend line to 1.1 million appears to be settling on early to mid May 21. https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2020-03-01..latest&country=~CAN&region=World&casesMetric=true&interval=smoothed&smoothing=7&pickerMetric=total_cases&pickerSort=desc Interesting to see the impact the new case counting approach (taken from 1st Feb 21) has had on the trend line: much more significant than I’d imagined. https://health-infobase.canada.ca/covid-19/epidemiological-summary-covid-19-cases.html#updateDetails
The rates of new cases has been steadily dropping for the last week.  If the trend holds the line will be hit the target in May

Additional confidence in original forecast (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1226866) given that the data "blip" on 1st Feb 21 with the new counting method has shown itself to be just that. Trend path is continuing downwards at a rate of between -200 and -150 per day. With lower summer rates of infection vs better testing and tracing methods, new travel restrictions vs new variants, slow and steady pace of Canadian vaccine rollout etc. all playing against each other a projected average of 3000 - 3500 new cases per day seems to remain valid for now.

But

Since 8 Jan peak; numbers have been dropping slowly - therefore we should expect a continued drop of daily case numbers. This puts weight around mid/late may or into June.  Seasonal drop will help - as we enter into Spring and Summer.  New variants detected
Adjusting based on cases per day.

Currently at about 4k cases per day and looks like it's declining rapidly. Some rough numbers for hitting 1.1 million below: If they averaged 6k cases per day they would hit 1.1 million at 61 days from now, or March 27.
If averaging 4k cases per day 1.1 million would be 78 days from now, or April 22.
Averaging 2k cases per day 1.1 million would be 156 days from now, or July 10. They've dropped in cases a lot faster than I expected. It now looks very possible for them to average between 4k and 2k over the remaining period, and getting close to 2k seems obtainable. Always possible for cases to jump back up as well though, but I'm optimistic with vaccine rollout that we won't see another large wave, though smaller waves are possible I think. As a second check, there are 314k cases remaining before hitting 1.1 million, if between now and May 1 (87 days from now) they linearly dropped down to 2k cases per day, that would be 261k additional cases, which would still keep them under 1.1 million. Seems like that's very possible. Based on that I'm now leaning toward hitting it in May, with an even possibility of April and June. Canada 7 day rolling average cases: https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2020-03-01..latest&country=~CAN&region=World&casesMetric=true&interval=smoothed&smoothing=7&pickerMetric=total_cases&pickerSort=desc My last forecast followed about the same format, link to it is here to see how these estimates have changed since Jan. 22: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1221480

Canada currently has 785k.  Despite progress in past few weeks history of previous public health interventions suggests it will be difficult to push the daily case load much lower than than current levels, especially in QC and ON.  Also emergence of variants in Canada is a wild card that could drive new increase in cases.

Minor adjustment given the revised case counting approach that has now kicked in as of 1st Feb 21 (well spotted @SE_Meyer ). "As of February 1, 2021, reporting has been updated to include the new test-based metrics."
https://health-infobase.canada.ca/covid-19/epidemiological-summary-covid-19-cases.html#updateDetails Range of daily new case average* reaching 1.1million total cases seems to be floating around the end of Apr 21 / start of May 21 borderline now (numbers below): 3000 daily new case avg = 17th May 21
3500 daily new case avg = 1st / 2nd May 21
4000 daily new case avg = 21st April 21
4500 daily new case avg = 12th April 21  All to watch for in the next few days as the new counting approach settles down and the trend line clarifies itself. *still using "worldindata" 7 day rolling average rates as the easier to read presentation and more conservative estimate:  https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2020-03-01..latest&country=~CAN&region=World&casesMetric=true&interval=smoothed&smoothing=7&pickerMetric=total_cases&pickerSort=desc.  Worth bearing in mind that the PHAC numbers (which this question will resolve on) have consistently lagged behind the "ourworldindata" figures by about 1 to 1.5 days, which might have an impact in the event the question comes down to a borderline between one month and the next.
The increase in cases seems to be slowing, which by my count puts the end point around 3/30.  It is still right on the line!

Two footnotes are interesting today: "*Due to a reporting lag, Toronto Public Health is reporting approximately 300 additional cases, resulting in an overestimate of the daily counts. ** The new cases, deaths and tests reflect the net change between what provinces and territories are reporting for the current day and for the previous reported day. Some provinces and territories do not provide daily updates. A decrease in the number of provinces and territories reporting person-based testing metrics is anticipated with the change in reporting methodology to test-based metrics. On February 1, 2021, reporting will begin with the new test-based metrics."
https://health-infobase.canada.ca/covid-19/epidemiological-summary-covid-19-cases.html#updateDetails

daily case rates have been slowing down the last month.  I doubt they will spike suddenly after vaccine release (unless everyone thinks the world is immune and stops taking precautions. Fingers crossed that doesn't happen.) To make matters trickier, when I look at the standard deviation of average rates and apply that to the prediction of 3/31 or 4/1, the range grows to 3/25 to 4/4 with the growth being 1 standard deviation higher or lower.  This will obviously get more precise as we near the deadline.   I am betting on April because the recent trend is a decrease in daily case, which implies it will take longer to reach the deadline.
The Problems are the mutated  viruses when only one is Extreme strong it Would be Extreme dangerous, Maybe we have to create  genmanipulate  our Immunsystem With Batgens....

Canada has right  a total of 5000 cases a day and going down.  Total cases 750,000.  
At this pace, they'll accumulate 150 thousand a month.  It will take them 2+ months to reach  the 1.1 million. Although the curve is going down. 
There's very little chance, with the curve and the vaccine, that Canada will reach 1.1 and after 2 months.

Some math based on 22 Jan totals (706,495 cases). The peak daily case load was around 8,000 in late Dec-early Jan, most likely exacerbated by holiday travel and get-togethers and winter weather keeping people meeting indoors.  Since then, cases have decreased significantly back near the 2,000 per day level.  Even if there is another wave, it is doubtful cases would go near the previous peak of 8,000.  Assuming an average of 4,000 cases per day, it would take 98 days to get above 1.1 million - a date of late April. Numerous factors could tend or shorten this timeline. Things like mitigation policies, vaccination administration, and even weather can affect the case load growth rates.
Even with my own judgement on possible errors and avenues down the road, I still come up with a relatively high confidence sometime in May, Canada will record 1.1 million total cases of COVID.

I'm afraid the recent slowing in figures gives a false sense of security. Canada certainly is on a "reduce"-scenario path and in a similar position as in mid-December 2020. However, like elsewhere there's a large risk for raging infection waves in long-term care facilities, the 80+ years group thus are the group  with the highest incidence in the population. It seems Canada was able to avoid the worst scenarios and expectations for the time being, but there is plenty of examples where it can go the wrong way pretty quickly (e.g. Rep. Ireland).

According to
https://health-infobase.canada.ca/covid-19/epidemiological-summary-covid-19-cases.html?stat=num&measure=total_last7&map=pt#a2
there were 4,852 new confirmed cases on 24 January 2021. There is apparently a sharp drop in all provinces except from New Brunswick and Saskatchewan and a drop in particular in those provinces with the largest base of total reported cases so far (the main drivers of the pandemic in Canada), namely Alberta,  Ontario and Quebec. However, it appears premature to pick a later bin than March for several reasons, the most prominent of which is an earlier observation in the source PHAC's figures:
The daily differential of total cases for Canada often times exceeds the figure of daily new confirmed cases significantly (3 to 4 digits) without explanation. Consulting the daily new confirmed cases only could deliver a false impression of the trajectory of the real infection rate, caused by mismatching figures and revisions that are not announced. PHAC's figures are notoriously incomplete and unreliable.
I expect Canada to count 150,000 additional cases to cross 900k cases in total over the next three weeks by 17 February 2021 (daily average 7.2k cases), which would leave six more weeks for the remaining 200,000 new cases (average of 4.8k cases per day) to reach 1.1mn cases.
If 900k cases will not be reached by the end of February, then April is the most likely outcome of this question.

Opening forecast based on the latest from the WHO, "WorldInData" and @Ryan-Beck 's number crunch of projected case numbers. Additional factors:
-Vaccination programme progress (hopefully) balancing out the increased transmission potential of new variants
-current sharp downward trajectory for early 2021
-Improving weather conditions over the question period
-low likelihood of change / lifting of COVID restrictions by Canadian government I'm working off a forecast daily case average of 3000 per day (previous levels, slow vaccination programme impact, warming weather) leading to the 1.1million threshold being met in mid to late May 21.  Leaving a slight weighting to the earlier side of this forecast for the uncertainty factor. Currently at about 6k cases per day and looks like it's declining. Some rough numbers for hitting 1.1 million below: If they averaged 6k cases per day they would hit 1.1 million at 61 days from now, or March 24.
If averaging 4k cases per day 1.1 million would be 92 days from now, or April 24.
Averaging 2k cases per day 1.1 million would be 184 days from now, or July 25. To average below 4k cases per day they would have to have a pretty steady drop over the next month and then hold steady at some number below 4k. With vaccinations starting to ramp up in that time period I think there's a decent chance they're able to avoid another big wave. I think averaging 4k or a little above that is most likely, and I think they're about as likely to average 2k as they are to average well above 6k, so I kind of see those as the limits. As a second check, there are 368k cases remaining before hitting 1.1 million, if between now and May 1 (99 days from now) they linearly dropped down to 2k cases per day, that would be 396k additional cases, putting them over 1.1 million. Seems fairly unlikely for cases to drop a lot faster than that.
